questions.text: All are true about double blind clinical drug trial, EXCEPT ?

choices.text: It removes patient and investigator bias
The patients do not know which treatment they are receiving

questions.solution:
DOUBLE BLINDING:

  • In a double-blind trial, the patients as well as the investigator are blinded i.e. they don’t know who is receiving the study drug and who is receiving placebo.
  • It removes subject & investigator bias.
  • MC blinding seen.

OTHER TYPES OF BLINDING:

  • Single blinding: Subjects are not aware of treatment. Used to remove subject bias.
  • Triple binding: Subject, investigator & analyzer are not aware of treatment. Removes subject, investigator & analyzer bias. It isbest blinding.
  • Open study: Complete absence of blinding.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman complains of a throbbing headache, and presents with increasing difficulty in combing her hair, causing pain over the scalp and jaw pain while eating. She was diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica a year ago. A provisional diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is made. Which of the following blood values will increase in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Giant cell/ temporal arteritis: vasculitic condition of the temporal artery associated with polymyalgia rheumatica in a large proportion of patients.
  • Usually occurs in more elderly individuals
  • Presents with headache, scalp and temporal artery tenderness, jaw claudication (as jaw pain while eating) and occasional visual disturbance such as amaurosis fugax
  • ESR >100 mm/h - virtually diagnostic
  • The gold standard test is a temporal artery biopsy, which will show a granulomatous inflammatory infiltrate of the media and adventitia.

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of causal association, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Hill's criteria of causal association/ Surgeon general's criteria include:

  • Temporality
  • Specificity
  • Consistency
  • Strength [RR/ Odd's ratio]
  • Biological plausibility
  • Coherence
  • Dose response relationship
  • Cessation of exposure.

Sensitivity is a measure of validity of a screening test; not included in criterion.

questions.text: All of the following are an absolute contraindication for OCP, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Absolute contraindications of OCP'S: [Mnemonic: CLUTCH]

  • C-Cancers [breast, cervical]
  • L- Liver diseases [adenoma]
  • U- Uterine bleeding [ excessive & undiagnosed]
  • T-Thromboembolism
  • C- Cardiovascular diseases
  • H- Hyperlipidemia [congenital] Preganancy

Also remember,

  • Long-standing or complicated diabetes (with microvascular complications) is absolute contraindication.
  • Grade I hypertension is relative contraindication and Grade II is absolute.
  • Simultaneous use of some anti-epileptics is relatively contraindicated .

questions.text: Mass treatment is to control which one of the following disease ?
questions.solution:
MASS TREATMENT

  • All people in community are administered with drugs whether they have the disease or not. [irrespective of age & gender]
  • The mass treatment is used in control Yaws, Pinta, Bejel, Trachoma & Filariasis.
  • The existence of at least 4-5 cases of latent infection for each clinical case of active disease in the community is rationale for it.
  • Patients with a latent (incubating) infection may develop disease at any time. In such cases, mass treatment is a critical factor in the interruption of disease transmission.

questions.text: All of the following deals with Demographic processes, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Demographyis the scientific study of human population. It focuses its attention on three readily observable human phenomena:

  1. Changes in population size (growth or decline)
  2. Composition of the population and
  3. Distribution of population in space.

It deals with5 "demographic processes" like

  • fertility
  • mortality
  • marriage
  • migration &
  • social mobility

These five processes are continuously at work within a population determining size, composition and distribution.

She has been drinking heavily and her friends report that she is now drowsier following her fall. She opens her eyes when her name is called and starts talking about her assignments for college. She winces when her nail bed is pressed. Her score according to the Glasgow Coma Scale will be:

questions.text: Multiple exposures can be studied together in?
questions.solution:
• In Cohort study, multipleoutcomescan be studied together.
  • In Case control study, multipleexposurescan be studied together.

COHORT STUDY:

  • Time consuming & expensive study
  • Incidence & RR can be calculated [more accurate]
  • No recall bias
  • Ethical problems are present & is not useful for rare diseases
  • Loss of follow-up [attrition] can be seen - max allowable attrition rate is < 5% ; ideal retention rate ≥ 95%
  • HAWTHORN BIAS - study subjects alter their behavior without notice ; can be seen.

questions.text: A 28 year old lady delivered a healthy baby by caesarean section at hospital. Breastfeeding should be initiated within ?
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, initiate breast feeding

  • After a normal vaginal delivery: Within 1 hour
  • After a cesarean section: Within 4 hours

Current recommendation: Start breast feeding as early as possibleASAP.(Do not wait for 1 hour or 4 hours)

questions.text: A perimenopausal woman presented with a 4-week history of greenish discharge from her right nipple. On examination, the right nipple appears to have a ‘slit-like’ appearance and is retracted and non-tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This presentation is typical of mammary duct ectasia, which is common in perimenopausal women.
  • Nipple discharge:
    • ranges from milky, brown to a dirty green colour
    • Bilateral
    • associated with cyclical mastalgia.
  • Nipple retraction can cause suspicion of breast carcinoma.
  • But the presence of the slit in the nipple, along with the colour of the nipple discharge and the perimenopausal age of the patient, make it more likely to be duct ectasia.

questions.text: The most common cause of late Neonatal mortality in India is ?
questions.solution:
MCC of Neonatal mortality in India is Low birth weight and prematurity [Preterm birth].

Neonatal mortality rate :

  • NNMR is a good indicator of newborn health and care.
    • MCC of Early neonatal mortality: prematurity and congenital anomalies.
    • MCC of late neonatal mortality: Infections.
  • NNMR boys >NNMR girls.

EXTRA-EDGE:

  • MCC of still births - Maternal infections & abruptio placenta.
  • MCC of maternal deaths- direct cause: PPH ; indirect cause: Anemia.
  • MCC of perinatal mortality is LBW & prematurity.

questions.text: Multiple duodenal ulcers that are not amenable to conventional medical therapy is associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution: • Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is caused by a non-insulin secreting tumour of the pancreas, which releases high levels of gastrin-like hormone. This causes hyperacidity of the stomach and therefore predisposes to severe and extensive duodenal ulceration.

questions.text: Daily total iodine requirement during lactation ?
questions.solution:
• Daily total requirement of Iodine in :
    • Adult person [men/women]: 150 mcg
    • Pregnant women : 250 mcg
    • During lactation: 220-290 mcg
  • Lifetime requirement of iodine: 5 grams.

questions.text: A 56-year-old lady is having a total thyroidectomy for Graves’ disease. During a thyroidectomy for Graves’ disease, a 55 year old patient develops a thyroid storm and tachycardia. Which of the following is a feature not likely to be associated with thyroid storm?
questions.solution:
• Thyroid storm/ thyrotoxic crisis: acute rare manifestation of hyperthyroidism
  • May be precipitated by stress, surgery and infection.
  • Sudden release of thyroid hormones → thyroxine (T4) and/or triiodothyronine (T3) into the systemic circulation → an exaggerated thyrotoxicosis manifestation.
  • Features include:
    • Hyperventilation
    • Tachycardia
    • Fever
    • Agitation
    • Dehydration
    • Shock
    • cardiac arrhythmias
    • cardiac failure
    • coma; it can be fatal if not managed promptly
  • Most commonly in patients who have thyrotoxicosis secondary to Graves’ disease.

questions.text: Remote contamination of water is indicated by ?
questions.solution:
• Coliform organisms:
    • Primary & most reliable bacterial indicator for water quality.
    • E. coli is most important coliform indicator.
  • Fecal streptococci:
    • Indicate ‘recent contamination of water’.
  • Clostridium perfringens:
    • Indicate ‘remote contamination of water’.

questions.text: What is the Sound level above which tympanic membrane ruptures ?
questions.solution:
• Daily maximum tolerable sound level to human ear :85-90 dB.
  • Human ear is sensitive to sound frequency: 20-20,000 Hz.
  • Auditory fatigue appears in: 90 dB.
  • Sound level above which tympanic membrane rupture: 150 – 160 dB.
  • Permanent hearing loss : >100 dB.
  • Hospital ward, permissible level of sound : 22-35 dB.
  • Normal conversation: 60-70 dB.

questions.text: All of the following Anti-tubercular drug can be given safely during Pregnancy, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
• Streptomycin- It is ototoxic to the fetus and should not be used during pregnancy.
  • With the exception of streptomycin, the first line anti-TB drugs [isoniazid, rifampicin (rifampin), ethambutol and pyrazinamide] are safe for use in pregnancy.
  • Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) should be added to the drug treatmentoftuberculosisin allpregnantwomen taking isoniazid.

Pregnancy with TB:

  • Start ATT immediately irrespective of time of pregnancy / delivery - 2 months [HRE] + 7 months [HR] - total 9 months.
  • MDR-TB : Do MTP & then start ATT; If MTP can't be done, start ATT without kanamycin & ethionamide substituted with PAS till delivery.

questions.text: The variables that is measured on the Nominal scale is ?
questions.solution:
Scale of measurement:

1. CATEGORICAL SCALE - Include Nominal & Ordinal scales

2. DIMENTIONAL SCALE - Include Metric scale

Nominal scale Ordinal scale Metric scale
Definition Based on NOM (names); no specific order Based on ORD (order); grading into categories Based on ME (measurement); in terms of quantities
Examples Race, Religion, Country of birth, Clinical features, Sites of lymphadenopathy, Sex of child, Type of anemia, ABO blood group, Site of malignancy TNM staging (cancers) ,Severity of a disease, Social classes Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Weight, Height, Mid-arm circumference ,Blood pressure, Pulse rate, Temperature (°C, °F, K) scale

questions.text: All of the following can be the cause of Permanent hardness of water, EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
Hardness of water

  • Temporary hardness (carbonate hardness) is due to calcium & magnesium salts of bicarbonates.
  • Permanent hardness (non – carbonate hardness) is due to calcium & magnesium salts of sulfates, chlorides, nitrates.
  • Four main compounds causing hardness: calcium bicarbonates, magnesium bicarbonates, calcium sulfates, magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with jaundice. On investigation, his stool appears to be pale; urine is dark red in color. This patient also has a palpable gallbladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Tumour of the head of pancreas

questions.solution:
• Dark urine and pale stool: classic presentation of obstructive jaundice
  • Palpable gall-bladder makes stone-related disease unlikely.
  • Courvoisier’s law states that ‘in obstructive jaundice, the presence of a palpable gallbladder precludes the diagnosis of stones’.
  • Presence of gallstones → irritates gallbladder → wall fibrosis and thickening

questions.text: Corneal transparency is due to ?
questions.solution:
1. HEPARAN SULFATE

  • Present on cell surfaces.
  • Heparan sulfate contains negatively charged,repels negatively charged molecules and thus is important in glomerular filtration.

2. CHONDROITIN SULFATE-Present in Cartilage, Bone, Tendon.

3. DERMATAN SULFATE-Found in Skin, Blood vessels, valves

4. KERATAN SULFATE

  • Only GAG without uronic acid
  • Present in cornea & connective tissue
  • Responsible for Transparency of cornea.

questions.text: Inflammatory bowel disease does NOT have which one of the following as a systemic manifestation?
questions.solution:
• Systemic manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): Osteoporosis
    • Osteomalacia
    • Arthritis
    • Sacroiliitis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
    • Sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Inverse stretch reflex in muscle is mediated by ?
questions.solution:
• Golgi tendon organs detects muscle tension & rate of change in muscle tension
  • Located in muscle-tendons
  • Inverse stretch reflex
    • When tension in muscle increased, signals are transmitted by type Ib nerve fibers to inhibitory interneurons which inhibit alpha-motor neuron resulting in relaxation of entire muscle (lengthening reaction)

Muscle spindle:

  • Distributed throughout belly of muscle
  • Detect muscle length / rate of change of length of muscle
  • Function: involved in muscle stretch reflex
  • When muscle is stretched suddenly, excitation of muscle spindle causes

Reflex contraction of large skeletal muscles fibers of stretched muscle & allied synergistic muscle

Unmyelinated C-fibers:

  • Type “c” – fibers are small & unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulse at low velocities
  • Constitute greater than half of sensory fibers in most peripheral nerves & post- ganglionic autonomic fibers

Dorsal column of spinal cord:

  • Carry fine, touch, vibration, 2 point discrimination & proprioception from skin & joints

questions.text: From the list of options below which one is the most unlikely cause of mechanical intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
• Intestinal obstruction: divided into mechanical and paralytic obstruction (aka paralytic ileus).
  • Paralytic ileus: intestines are in a complete state of atony
    • Clinical features include abdominal distension, absolute constipation, vomiting and the absence of intestinal motility (thus bowel sounds are absent).
  • Causes of mechanical obstruction can be divided into:
    • Luminal (e.g. faecal impaction, foreign body, intussusceptions, large polyps)
    • Intramural (e.g. congential intestinal atresia, Crohn’s colitis, tumours, strictures)
    • Extraluminal (e.g. volvulus, adhesions, strangulated hernia, extrinsic compression also known as a ‘mass effect’)

questions.text: Vitamin K is essential for adding carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on all of the following clotting factors, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K leads to γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues to clotting factor 2,7,9 and 10

Vitamin K is essential for adding carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on 5 important clotting factors

  1. Prothrombin (II)
  2. Factor VII
  3. Factor IX
  4. Factor X
  5. Protein C

questions.text: The ankle brachial pressure index of a patient is measured during a peripheral vascular examination. Choose the correct among the following values reflecting a normal ankle–brachial pressure index?
questions.solution:
• ABPI: highest systolic blood pressure measured in any ankle artery (dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial artery) divided by the systolic pressure at the brachial artery.
  • Performed using a Doppler and blood pressure cuff.
  • The cuff is inflated above the artery while the Doppler probe → connected to a pulse volume recorder → placed just below or at the site of the artery → cuff is gently deflated → pressure, at which the first pulse sound is heard, is noted.
  • An ABPI greater than or equal to 1.0 is usually normal.
  • ABPI values between 0.9 and 0.6: peripheral vascular occlusive disease (eg. intermittent claudication).
  • ABPI between 0.6 and 0.3:critical limb ischaemia and these patients usually have limb pain at rest.
  • ABPI less than or equal to 0.3: impending gangrene of the affected limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for the quick diagnosis of an aortic dissection?
questions.solution: • CT scan: rapid diagnosis of an aortic dissection although MRI has a greater sensitivity.

questions.text: Muscle spindle function is?

choices.text: Detects the dynamic change in muscle length

questions.solution:
There are two proprioceptors in a muscle: -

Muscle spindle Golgi tendon organ
  • Situated in belly or muscle
  • Formed byintra-fusal fibres
  • Detects the length of muscle when muscle is stationary
  • Detect rate of change of length
  • Present in tendon
  • Made up of tendon fibres
  • Detects the muscle tension.
  • Detects rate of change of tension.

questions.text: Regarding the epidemiology of hypertension, all the following statemnts are true EXCEPT:

choices.text: In individuals 60 years or older, average systolic blood pressure is higher in women.
Diastolic blood pressure increases steadily with age.
Hypertension prevalence is lower in Dravidians than Caucasians.
Blood pressure increases steadily during the first two decades of life, in developed nations.

questions.solution:
• In adults, diastolic blood pressure increases steadily with age until 55 years.
  • Decreases after 55 years
  • Results in widening of pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure) beyond the age of 60.

questions.text: An asthma patient is brought to the ER with status asthmaticus. All of the following pathologic findings are likely to be seen in this person EXCEPT:

choices.text: Infiltration of the airway mucosa with eosinophils and neutrophils
Infiltration of the alveolar spaces with eosinophils and activated T lymphocytes
Occlusion of the airway lumen by mucous plugs
Thickening and edema of the airway wall

questions.solution:
• Airways: infiltrated by eosinophils, activated T lymphocytes, and activated mucosal mast cells.
  • Degree of inflammation does not correlate with the severity of asthma.
  • In eosinophilic bronchitis: thickening of the basement membrane due to collagen deposition in the subepithelium, airway smooth muscle hypertrophy.
  • Hence, thickening of the airway wall, possibly with edematous fluid, especially in fatal asthma (where mucus plugs are seen).

questions.text: All are true about Bainbridge reflex, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Bainbridge reflex:

  • Increase in atrial pressure causes increase in heart rate by nervous reflex called Bainbridge reflex 40 – 60 % increase in rate is due to this reflex while 15% increase is by direct effect of increased atrial volume to stretch sinus node.
  • Stretch receptors of atria that elicit Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through vagus nerve to medulla of brain.
  • These efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal & sympathetic nerves to increase H.R & strength of heart contraction.
  • This reflex helps prevent damming of blood in atria, veins & pulmonary circulation

  • Best known nerve mechanisms for arterial pressure control
  • Reflex is initiated by stretch receptors called baroreceptors /pressoreceptors located at specific points in walls of several large systemic arteries
  • A rise in arterial pressure stretches baroreceptor & causes them to transmit signals into CNS.
  • “feedback” signals are then sent back through autonomic nervous system to circulation to reduce arterial pressure downward towards the normal level

questions.text: AKI evaluation in a patient, who has recently undergone a cardiopulmonary bypass, which of the following urine microscopy findings suggests cholesterol emboli, as the source of renal failure?
questions.solution: • Cholesterol emboli: cause of AKI in cardiac surgery patients with atherosclerotic disease (which may get disrupted and shower cholesterol emboli)

questions.text: All of the following are true about Decerebrate rigidity except:-

choices.text: Extension of both upper and lower extremity
Flexion of upper extremity and extension of lower extremity
Reticulo spinal tract is also involved

questions.solution:
Decerebrate rigidity:

  • When brain stem of animal is sectioned below midlevel of mesencephalon but pontine & medullary reticular systems as well as vestibular system are intact, this is decerebrate animal This results in rigidity of antigravity muscles à muscles of neck & trunk & extensors (i.e all extensors go into spasm) This decerebrate rigidity is due to blockage of normally strong input to medullary reticular nuclei from cerebral cortex, Red nuclei & the basal ganglion. Lacking this input, medullary reticular inhibitor system becomes nonfunctional, full overactivity of pontine excitatory system occurs & rigidity develops. (Due to exaggerated gamma motor neuron discharge) Decorticate rigidity: Thick layer of cortex is removed & all other structures are preserved. This results in decorticate rigidity à flexors of upper limb & extensors of lower limb goes into spasm (flexion).

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding alcoholic liver disease are true EXCEPT:

choices.text: Fatty liver is present in > 90% of daily and binge drinkers.
Hepatitis C infection: worsens alcoholic liver disease prognosis.
More than 50% of alcoholics will develop alcoholic hepatitis.
The pathologic hallmarks of alcoholic liver disease are fatty liver, hepatitis, and cirrhosis.

questions.solution:
• Fatty liver is present in >90% of daily as well as binge drinkers.
  • A much smaller percentage of heavy drinkers will progress to alcoholic hepatitis, a precursor to cirrhosis.
  • Although alcohol is considered a direct hepatotoxin, only between 10% and 20% of alcoholics will develop alcoholic hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is facilitated by colipase ?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic juice containslipase, colipase, phospholipase A & B

Colipase:

  • Facilitates the action of lipase
  • Prevents inactivation of lipase by bile salts

questions.text: A patient, with episodic abdominal pain and stress-induced edema of the tongue, lips and larynx is likely to have low functional or absolute levels of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
• The activated C1 is destroyed by a plasma protease inhibitor: C1 esterase inhibitor.
  • C1 esterase inhibitor also regulates: clotting factor XI, kallikrein
  • Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor:angioedema → possibly leading to death by asphyxia.

questions.text: Which of the following reflex stretches the walls of heart chamber that results in contraction of cardiac muscle with increased force ?
questions.solution:
Bainbridge reflex(atrial reflex control of heart rate):

  • Increase in atrial pressure cause increase in H.R; as much as 75 percent sometimes.
  • Small part of increase is caused by direct effect of increased atrial volume which stretches sinus node resulting in increased H.R by 15 percent.
  • Additional 40 – 60% increase in H.R is caused by nervous reflex called Bainbridge reflex.
    • Stretch receptors of atria that elicit Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through vagus nerve to medulla of brain.
    • These efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal & sympathetic nerves to increase H.R & strength of heart contraction.
    • This reflex helps prevent damming of blood in veins, atria & pulmonary circulation.

ØFrank-starling mechanism of heart:

  • When increased quantities of blood flows into heart, it stretches walls of heart chamber which results in contraction of cardiac muscle with increased force.
  • This action empties extra blood that has entered from systemic circulation (by increasing cardiac output).

ØVago-vagal reflex:

  • When food stretches the stomach, vago-vagal reflex from stomach to brainstem & then back to stomach, reduces the tone in muscular wall of body of stomach so that wall bulges progressively outwards, accommodating greater quantities of food up to a limit in completely relaxed stomach of 0.8 – 1.5 lit .
  • Pressure in the stomach remains low until this limit is approached

ØBezold jarisch reflex:

  • Prolonged upright posture results in some degree of pooling of blood in lower extremities resulting in decreased ventricular filling which stimulate receptors in ventricles resulting in hypopnea, bradycardia (paradoxical reflex).

questions.text: After the neurosurgical resection of a pituitary tumor, which of the following mentioned adrenal gland function will be preserved post-operatively?

choices.text: Na+ retention, in response to hypovolemia
Cortisol release, as a stress response
Morning peak of plasma cortisol level

questions.solution:
• The adrenal gland functions: glucocorticoid synthesis, aldosterone synthesis, and androgen precursor synthesis.
  • Glucocorticoid synthesis: controlled by ACTH secretion from the pituitary.
  • Aldosterone synthesis: Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (independent of the pituitary).
  • Hence, morning cortisol secretion and release of cortisol in response to stress: regulated by the pituitary gland
  • Regulation of sodium retention and potassium excretion by aldosterone: independent of the pituitary, and hence would be preserved in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: True about Bowditch’s effect ?
questions.solution:
Bowditch’s effect:

  • Bowditch was a German physiologist.
  • He put forth the term Treppe, which meansstaircase.
  • If youincrease the frequency of a stimulus to a muscle, each succeedingcontraction would be strongerthan a preceding one.
  • This effect has been c/a The staircase effect or Bowditch’s effect.
  • An increase in the frequency of stimulation results in increasing strength of contraction.
  • The physiological basis for this effect is increased sarcoplasmic calcium.
  • Strength of contraction of muscle∝amount of sarcoplasmic calcium.

questions.text: Best candidate, with Parkinson's disease, for deep brain stimulation is which one of the following?

choices.text: 62 year old woman on levodopa-carbidopa, with episodes of freezing while walking
69 year old man, with orthostatic hypotension and recurrent falls
72 year old woman; unresponsive to dopaminergic therapy and with severe tremor
75 year old man; with worsening dementia symptoms

questions.solution:
• Deep brain stimulation (DBS):
  • Electrode placed into a target area, typically the subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus pars interna → electrode is connected to a stimulator usually placed in the chest wall.
  • Once in place, DBS is adjusted on many variables: voltage, frequency, pulse duration.
  • The primary DBS indication: severe tremor or levodopa-induced motor complications unresponsive to medications.
  • DBS does not improve features that fail to respond to levodopa treatment: falling, freezing, and dementia.

questions.text: Plateau phase of cardiac action potential :
questions.solution:
In cardiac action potential

Phase O→ Rapid upstroke → due to fast sodium channels → Influx of Na+

Phase I→ Initial repolarization → fast Na channels → close

Phase II→ Plateau → due to calcium influx

Phase III→ Rapid repolarization → Calcium channels close & slow potassium channels open

Phase IV→ Resting membrane potential → - 90 mv

questions.text: A woman, 12 weeks pregnant with her first child, has an abnormal finding on a CBC. She is asymptomatic, and has no family history of significant anemias. Hb: 12.1 g/dL, hematocrit: 38%, MCV: 60 fL, MCH: 25 pg, ferritin: 50 μg/L, iron: 15 μmol/L. On a PBS, what is the most characteristic finding expected?
questions.solution:
• Individuals with the α-thalassemia trait: asymptomatic microcytosis and hypochromia (low MCV and low MCH), no anemic.
  • α-Thalassemia trait: defect in two of the α-globin genes (-α/-α or --/αα)
  • Production of α-globin: gives normal hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Characteristic finding on peripheral blood smear: Target cell -- bulls-eye appearance, also be seen in liver disease.
  • Burr cells: seen in uremia; multiple spiny projections
  • Howell-Jolly bodies: nuclear remnants
  • Spherocytes: small dense RBCs, lacking central pallor and biconcavity, seen in hereditary spherocytosis and other autoimmune hemolytic anemias.

questions.text: Which of the following has been shown in randomized trials to reduce the future risk of pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
• The results from multiple large, double-blind, randomized chemoprevention trials have established 5α-reductase inhibitors as the main therapy to reduce the future risk of a prostate cancer diagnosis.
  • Randomized placebo-controlled trials have shown that finasteride and dutasteride reduce the period prevalence of prostate cancer.
  • Trials of selenium, vitamin C, and vitamin E have shown no benefit versus placebo.

questions.text: During the course of psychotherapy the patient said to therapist that he gets sexual arousal by physical suffering or injury inflicted on him by others. The given condition is ?
questions.solution:
• Masochism: when a person gets sexual gratification by physical/ psychological humiliation, injury inflicted on him by others.

Incorrect options

  • Exhibitionism: Getting sexual arousal by exposing one’s genitalia to an stranger.
  • Sadism: when a person gets sexual gratification by physical/ psychological humiliation, injury or suffering of the sexual partner.
  • Fetishism: Sexual arousal by inanimate objects/ non genital parts. Usually seen in heterosexual males.

questions.text: A 23 year old female was brought to hospital on 4th day post delivery. Guardians stated that the patient seemed very irritable and sad for past 2 days.
questions.solution:
• Postpartum blues: Depressed affect, fatigue and tearfulness starts 2 - 5 days postpartum and usually resolves within 2 weeks.

Incorrect options

  • Postpartum depression: Sadness, tearfulness, sleep disturbances, suicidal thoughts/ thoughts of harming baby/ guilt; starts within 3 months postpartum
  • Postpartum psychosis: Tearfulness, sleep disturbances, delusion , hallucination, risk of harm to self or baby; starts within 2-3 weeks.
  • Cyclothymic disorder: Mood typically oscillates between hypomania and dysthymia. Patient should have symptoms for at least 2 years .

questions.text:
Match the EEG recordings
A) Stage 1 1) Sleep spindles
B) Stage 2 2) Alpha wave
C) Stage 4 3) Theta wave
D) Awake 4) Delta wave
questions.solution:
Awake Alpha wave
Stage 1 Theta wave
Stage 2 Sleep spindles, K complexes
Stage 3 Appearance of Delta wave
Stage 4 Predominance of delta wave

questions.text: A 21 year old male was brought to hospital with the history of using heroin and stopped using for past 2 days. What is unlikely to be seen ?
questions.solution:
OPIOID WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS

  • Starts in 6-8 hrs of withdrawal
  • Reach peak in 2-3 days
  • Ends in 7-10 days
  • Causes flu like symptoms
  • Lacrimation, sweating, rhinorrhea, diarrhea
  • Yawning
  • Piloerection
  • Mydriasis
  • Body ache and insomnia
  • Hypertension and anxiety
  • Tachycardia

questions.text: A 13 year boy was brought to hospital with an incised wound. On examination wound is clean and uninflected. In the process of healing by 1st intention ( primary union) when will the new collagen fibrils start forming?
questions.solution:
Day 00 Blood clot
Day 01 Blood clot + Neutrophilic infiltration
Day 02 Day 01 + thin epithelial layer
Day 03 Granulation tissue ( macrophages, fibrous tissues, angiogenesis)
Day 04/05 GT + collagen deposition ( typeIII)
Day 14 high collagen deposition + fibrous tissue
  • Maximum angiogenesis seen at day 5
  • 3 - 4 weeks collagen III is replaced by collagen I

Incorrect options

  • Option B: high collagen deposition + fibrous tissue
  • Option C: Granulation tissue ( macrophages, fibrous tissues, angiogenesis)
  • Option D: Blood clot + Neutrophilic infiltration

questions.text: A 34 years male underwent a renal transplantation surgery. Half and hour after the procedure their was Graf rejection. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction ( cytotoxic)

  • Reaction of humoral antibodies that attack cell surface antigens and cause cell lysis
  • Examples
    • MY : myasthenia gravis
    • Blood : Blood transfusion reactions, Rh incompatibility
    • Group : Good pasture syndrome ; Graves’ disease
    • Is : immune hemolytic anemia ; immune thrombocytopenia
    • R : Rheumatic fever
    • H : hyper acute transplant rejection
    • Positive : Pernicious anemia ; pemphigus vulgaris

Incorrect options

  • Option B : Type I HR is a rapidly developing immune response in a previously sensitized person ( Eg; food allergy, hey fever, bronchial asthma )
  • Option C : Type III HR results from deposition of antigen - antibody complex on tissue ( Eg; immune complex glomerulonephritis, drug induced vasculitis)
  • Option D : Type IV HR is a slow and delayed response

questions.text: A 22 year female came with the complains of lower abdominal pain and diarrhea for past 2 days. Histopathology finding are show in the image given below. The following statements are true regarding the causative agent except

choices.text: Active adult form ( trophozoites) are seen in tissues and diarrheal stool
Cystic form is seen only in formed stools
Trophozoite and cyst are passed in stools
Trophozoites are the infectious stage of the parasite and are found in contaminated food and water

questions.solution:
Amebiasis

  • Causative agent is Entamoeba histolytica
    • Active adult form ( trophozoites) are seen in tissues and diarrheal stool
    • Cystic form is seen only in formed stools but not seen in tissues
    • Trophozoite and cyst are passed in stools
    • The cysts are the infectious stage of the parasite and are found in contaminated food and water
  • Clinical manifestation
    • Symptoms may develop 2- 6 weeks after the ingestion of cysts
    • A gradual onset of lower abdominal pain with mild diarrhea
    • Flask shaped ulcers are seen
    • Primarily intestine is involved → Penetration of trophozoites into portal circulation reaching liver → Amoebic liver abscess [Anchovy sauce pus]

questions.text: A 38 year male came to hospital with the complaint of diarrhea ( watery and mucoid ) 4 times a day for past 3 days . He gave history of antibiotic use. What is the causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Pseudomembranous colitis

  • Aka antibiotic associated colitis
  • 3rd generation cephalosporin → alteration at the level of gut flora → Excessive proliferation of clostridium difficile → Toxins from clostridium difficile cause large intestinal inflammation
  • Pseudomembrane is due to exudative lesions.
  • “Volcano eruption” like appearance/ “Mushroom appearance
  • Diagnosis
    • PCR for toxin
  • Treatment
    • Oral Vancomycin > Metronidazole
    • For recurrent cases: Fecal microbiota transplantation

questions.text: A neonate was brought to hospital with the complaints of failure to pass meconium and abdominal distention. On examination squirt sign is positive. Rectal suction biopsy was taken which is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. Which of the following statement is correct ?

choices.text: Acetylcholinesterase is highly expressed, Calretinin is absent
Acetylcholinesterase is absent , Calretinin is highly expressed
Both Acetylcholinesterase and Calretinin are highly expressed

questions.solution:
• In Hirschsprung disease there is loss / under activity of RET gene
  • Failure of migration of neural crest cells into the bowel → absents of ganglionic cells (aganglionosis)
  • Proximal part of the affected bowel will be dilated and affected segment will be contracted
  • Clinical features
    • failure of passage of meconium leading to abdominal distention
    • chronic constipation
    • Dilatation of segment leads to thinning of bowel wall
  • Diagnosis: confirmed by rectal suction biopsy
Normal Hirschsprung disease
AchE - Highly expressed
calretinin + -

questions.text: A 12 year old male came to hospital with the complaints of hematuria, peri-orbital edema, fever. Patient has history of sore throat 10 days back. Urine analysis showed decreased urine output, RBC cast (+), Proteinuria. Given are the features of Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis except?
questions.solution:
• MC cause of glomerulonephritis in children
  • Type III hypersensitivity reaction
  • During active glomerulonephritis complement level goes down, when condition improves complement level comes to normal know as transient hypocomplementemia
  • Electron microscopic finding : electron dense irregular deposits (immune complex deposition ) on Sub epithelium gives characteristic ”sub epithelial hump “
  • Starry sky appearance is also a characteristic feature of Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Spike and dome appearance is a feature of membranous glomerulopathy

questions.text: The following pharmacological tests 4 are useful in differentiating a patient with a fixed dilated pupil:
questions.solution:
• Cocaine test is used to confirm Horner's syndrome and 2.5% phenylephrine or 0.1 % adrenaline are used to localise the site in Horner's syndrome.
  • 0.01 % pilocarpine causes constriction of Adie's pupil.
  • 1% pilocarpine will constrict a dilated pupil caused by third nerve palsy but will not constrict a pharmacologically dilated pupil.

questions.text: Increased pigmentary deposition in the angles is seen in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
• Latanoprost increases melanin production in the melanocytes.
  • But it does not cause increased pigmentary deposition in the angle.

questions.text: Which of the following pairings are incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Gerstmann's syndrome results from a lesion in the dominant parietal lobe.
  • It is characterised by acalculia, agraphia, finger agnosia and left-right confusion.
  • Prosopagnosia is an inability to recognise familiar faces and usually results from bilateral occipitotemporal involvement.
  • Achromatopsia is abnormal colour discrimination and can arise from bilateral parietal or occipital lobe abnormalities.
  • Akinetopsia implies insensitivity to motion and can result from a lesion in the middle temporal gyrus.

questions.text: Which of the following features distinguishes optic disc swelling from papilloedema?

choices.text: The presence of relative afferent pupillary defect
Leakage of fluorescein from the optic nerve head during fluorescein angiography

questions.solution:
• Optic disc swelling causes abnormal optic nerve function with a relative afferent pupillary defect, colour desaturation and decreased visual acuity.
  • Absence of venous pulsation, an enlarged blind spot and leakage of fluorescein from the optic nerve head occur in both optic disc swelling and papilloedema.

questions.text: In a 35 year old female patient presenting with headache and papilloedema, a CT scan displayed normal ventricles. Which one of the following is the most likely provisional diagnosis in such a patient?
questions.solution:
• Idiopathic/ benign intracranial hypertension (IIH), aka Pseudotumor cerebri - usually found in obese young females.
  • Characterised by:
    • chronic headache
    • bilateral papilloedema
    • without any ICSOLs (intracranial space occupying lesions)
    • Without enlargement of the ventricles due to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A patient with a diagnosed optic chiasmic lesion would have any of the following visual defects, except?
questions.solution:
• At the centre of the optic chiasma, the fibres from the nasal retina of both eyes cross over to the other side.
  • Hence any lesion affecting the centre of the chiasma will cause Bitemporal hemianopia or Heteronymous hemianopia
    • Sometimes, in early cases the hemianopia may be incomplete either heteronymous upper temporal or lower temporal
  • In the periphery of the chiasm are the fibres from the temporal retina of both the eyes.
    • Thus a peripheral lesion may lead to Binasal hemianopia (rare).

questions.text: Secondary deviation is more than primary deviation. This is a feature of which of the following occurrences?
questions.solution:
• Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint.
  • In incomitant squint, secondary deviation is more than primary deviation.

questions.text: In a patient with myopia of 0.5D from a distance of 1 meter, when performing retinoscopy, where will the reflex move?

choices.text: The reflex will move opposite to the mirror
The reflex will move with the mirror
The reflex may move on either side
There will be no movement of the reflex

questions.solution: • As the refractive error is myopia <1 D, the reflex will move with the mirror.

questions.text: A 28 day old neonate presented to the ER with jaundice. Serum bilirubin: 4.2 mg/dL, abdomen USG: gallbladder is shrunken, extrahepatic ducts not seen. Which is the best initial management in this infant?
questions.solution:
• Biliary atresia treatment: laparotomy with Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy.
  • Biliary atresia characterized by: progressive obliteration of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts → irreversible hepatic fibrosis.

questions.text: A man is newly diagnosed with a squamous cell carcinoma thought to be of the internal jugular lymph node chain on the right side. CT, MRI head and neck: negative for a primary malignancy. Select the next appropriate step in the assessment of this patient.

choices.text: Selective sampling of cervical lymph nodes
Neck ultrasound: thyroid and bilateral cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
• Cervical lymph node metastases with unknown primary: most common site is in upper aerodigestive tract.
  • So, the next step after negative imaging: pan or triple endoscopy (laryngoscopy, nasopharyngoscopy, and esophagoscopy (upper endoscopy)), with tissue biopsies during endoscopy.

questions.text: CT head scan: 32-year-old female, B/L frontal lobe contusions. She has a GCS of 5. Best initial management of this patient is:

choices.text: Observation with anticonvulsive medication administration for 7 days

questions.solution: • In any patient of GCS <8, ICP monitor should be placed for management of possible intracranial hypertension.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man receives 3 units of packed red blood cells during a particularly difficult surgery. He is bleeding heavily from his perineal surgical wound, 4 hours later. Lab values: normal prothrombin, partial thromboplastin, and bleeding times, non-elevated fibrin degradation products, serum fibrinogen content: reduced and platelet count is 75,000/μL. Most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Blood vessel bleed in the surgical region

questions.solution: • Significant bleeding in the early postoperative period: almost always error in surgical control of blood vessels

questions.text: After an uneventful laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a 49 year old woman receives 1 dose of cephalosporin. She returns to the ER with fever, nausea, and copious diarrhea, after a week, and is suspected of having pseudomembranous colitis. Patient is afebrile, with no peritoneal signs on abdominal examination, mild left-shift leukocytosis. Most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of C difficile colitis: metronidazole for first-line therapy; oral vancomycin as a second-tier agent.
  • Anti-diarrheal agents: contraindicated in suspected C difficile colitis, might prolong the infection.

questions.text: A toddler, 3-year-old, is diagnosed with a chemical burn after spilling bleach on his lower extremities. His clothing is removed and resuscitation is administered. Which is the most appropriate initial management along with these measures?

choices.text: Neutralization of burn wound with weak acids.
Lavage of burn wound with large volumes of water.

questions.solution:
• Treatment of alkali chemical burns: immediate removal of the alkali agent with large volumes of water lavage.
  • Alkalis: dissolve and unite with proteins of the tissues → form alkaline proteinates which have hydroxide ions → further chemical reactions and penetration deeper into the tissue.
  • Neutralization attempts of the alkali with weak acids: not recommended as the heat released by neutralization reactions causes further injury.

questions.text: On examination of a 1 cm skin lesion on the forearm of a man, it appears to have a waxy appearance with rolled, pearly borders around a central ulcer. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinomas (BCCs):
    • slow growth rate
    • infiltrate locally
    • rarely metastasize
  • Small lesions (< 2 mm): curettage, electrodesiccation, or laser vaporization
  • Surgical excision: most appropriate method of resection, due to the size and location of this patient’s lesion.

questions.text: Image shown is the small intestinal mucosal Biopsy of a patient with celiac sprue. Following are the features of celiac sprue except

choices.text: Can be associated with syndromes like down’s, Turners, Klinefelter syndrome

questions.solution:
• Gluten sensitive enteropathy
  • Immunological mediated damage At the level of the intestine.
  • Predominantly involves proximal part of small intestine
  • Order of severity: Duodenum > Jejunum
  • Histological findings
    • Atrophy of villi
    • Hyperplasia of crypts
    • No change in mucosal thickness
  • Wheat, Barley, Rye, oats: Should be avoided
  • Diagnosis
    • Atrophy of villi, Hyperplasia of crypts, unaltered mucosal thickness
    • Intestinal biopsy
    • Serological markers: Anti transglutaminase antibody, anti-endomysium antibody
  • High chance of developing iron deficiency anemia (if duodenum involved)
  • High chance of developing folic acid deficiency (If jejunum involved)
  • Risk for developing
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • SI adenocarcinoma
    • SCC of esophagus
  • Can be associated with syndromes like down’s, Turners, Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Complications associated
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis [IgA present at the level of dermal papillae]
  • Treatment
    • Serial substitution (Maze, Rice, Quinoa)
  • Leading cause of mortality: GIT lymphoma (EATL)
  • Diagnosis : Biopsy (Twice)
    • One initially
    • Second is repeated after 4 weeks of complete dietary elimination of serials (Wheat, Barley, Rye, oats) in which villous regrowth can be seen.
  • Complication like Type 1 DM is also seen in patients with Celiac sprue [So regular follows up is required]

questions.text: A man with a single gunshot wound to the left thigh is brought to the ER. He has a large hematoma on his medial thigh and complains of paresthesias in his left foot. On examination, weak pulses palpable distal to the injury, inability to move foot. Most appropriate initial management of this patient is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Immediate exploration and repair: mandatory for acute arterial insufficiency with neurologic symptoms.
  • Exploration is done in the presence of “hard signs”:
    • expanding hematoma
    • pulsatile bleeding
    • audible bruit
    • palpable thrill
    • absent distal pulses
    • distal ischemia
  • “Soft signs” include:
    • hypotension/shock
    • history of hemorrhage at the site of injury
    • peripheral nerve deficit
    • stable hematoma, l

questions.text: A patient with a 50-year history of cigarette smoking presents with a nontender, hard mass in lateral neck. Best diagnostic test to establish malignancy diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Isolated enlarged cervical lymph nodes in adults: malignant almost 80% of the time
  • Usually metastatic squamous cell carcinomas
  • Fine-needle aspiration cytology: used to obtain histologic confirmation of suspected cancer

questions.text: A 13 year old male came with the Melanotic pigmentation of lip. Open further investigations he was found to have multiple, pedunculated polyps of variable size in small intestine. What is the inheritance of this condition ?
questions.solution:
• Peutz Jegher Polyps
    • Hamartomatous polyps
    • Sporadic varient
      • Pubertal age group
    • Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle cells and epithelial cells/ “Tree branch” appearance
    • Familial variant/ Peutz jegher syndrome
      • Gene involved: STK gene
      • Family history (+)
      • Hyperpigmentation at the level of mucosa (particularly buccal mucosa)
      • Autosomal dominant
      • High risk of developing malignancy in SI > Colon > Pancreases, Breast, lungs
    • Surveillance
      • Sex cord stromal tumor in testicular tissue at birth
      • Stomach/ SI cancer in childhood

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with hypertension, obesity, and new skin striae. You are concerned about possible Cushing syndrome. Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Cushing syndrome: MCC is iatrogenic, via administration of synthetic corticosteroids
  • Cushing syndrome: clinical manifestations of glucocorticoid excess due to any cause (Cushing disease, administration of exogenous glucocorticoids, adrenal carcinoma or adenine, ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors)

questions.text: A college student, with a bulge in his right groin, notices that it is accentuated with coughing, but is easily reducible. Which of the following hernias has the path of the spermatic cord within the cremaster muscle?
questions.solution: • Indirect inguinal hernia → leaves abdominal cavity through the dilated internal inguinal ring → passes along anteromedial aspect of the spermatic cord.

questions.text: A 40 year old male came with the complaints of weight loss, diarrhea, peripheral edema. He was diagnosed with menetrier disease. Following statement are true except

choices.text: Diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium of antrum

questions.solution:
• Example of Gastropathy
  • Excessive Epithelial cell proliferation
  • Prominent rugal folds are seen
  • Hypoproteinemia
  • Secondary symptoms : weight loss, secretory diarrhea, peripheral edema
  • Histologically
    • Foveolar Cell hyperplasia of body and fundus
  • Predisposing factor to develop gastric adenocarcinoma.
  • Characterized by increased in concentration of TgF-α1 [reason for foveolar cell hyperplasia].

questions.text:
Match the individual actions of interleukins
A) IL-6 1) Normal functioning of B/T cell (defect causes SCID)
B) IL-7 2) Secreted by T cells, responsible for recruitment of neutrophils (eg; in hepatitis)
C) IL-10 3) Systemic effects of inflammation
D) IL-17 4) Anti inflammatory action
questions.solution:
IL 1 Systemic effects of inflammation
IL 2 Autocrine action; increases T lymphocytes
IL 4 B cell proliferation & differentiation
IL 5 B cell proliferation & differentiation
IL 6 Systemic effects of inflammation
IL 7 Normal functioning of B/T cell (defect causes SCID)
IL 11 Increases platelets
IL 3 Haematopoietic precursor cell proliferation
IL 10 Anti inflammatory action
IL 17 Secreted by T cells, responsible for recruitment of neutrophils (eg; in hepatitis, kaposis sarcoma)

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old man presents to the ER with sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. ECG: normal, CXR: 40% left pneumothorax. Which of the following procedures is considered appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• Spontaneous pneumothorax: usually due to rupture of subpleural blebs in young men (age 20-40 years)
  • Presents with sudden onset of chest and shoulder pain
  • Large pneumothorax: chest tube requirement; thoracotomy with bleb excision, pleural abrasion

questions.text: On an routine ophthalmic examination physician noted Kayser Fleischer ring in an patient. Following are the biochemical abnormalities seen in relation to this condition except

choices.text: Increased hepatic copper in liver biopsy
Serum copper levels may vary upon the stage of disease

questions.solution:
Wilson’s disease

  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Mutation in ATP7B gene of chromosome 13
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin because of impaired synthesis of apoceruloplasmin and due to defective mobilization of copper from hepatocellular lysosomes.
  • Increased hepatic copper in liver is because of excessive accumulation of copper in the liver
  • Increased urinary excretion of copper
  • Serum copper levels may vary from low-to-normal-to-high depending upon the stage of disease
  • Sunflower cataract and Kayser Fleischer ring (as copper deposits in Descemet’s membrane)

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and weight loss. Upper endoscopy shows no evidence of malignancy, esophageal motility studies: incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. Next best step in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Laparoscopic myotomy of lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
• Achalasia- motility disorder of esophagus, usually affects persons between 30 and 50 years of age.
  • Treatment options:
    • botulinum toxin injection into lower esophageal sphincter
    • balloon dilation
    • surgical myotomy of lower esophageal sphincter (Heller myotomy)

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with Peripheral Artery Occlusive Disease. He has a surgical history of a triple coronary artery bypass 3 years years ago. He is taking only a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to manage this patient’s atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Antiplatelet agents: used to prevent thrombotic, embolic events in arterial circulation.
  • Aspirin has an antiplatelet effect: lasting for the life of the platelet ( 7-10 days).
  • Aspirin: interferes with platelet function → this is done by inhibiting synthesis of thromboxane A2 and production of prostaglandins.

questions.text: A 10 year old male was brought to hospital with the complaints of dyspnea, wheezing. He is allergic to crustaceans, dust and pollen. Investigations are done to this patient. Following are the microscopic findings seen in this patient except
questions.solution:
Bronchial asthma

  • Sputum findings (3C)
    • Curschmann’s spirals: Mucus plugs containing normal and degenerated respiratory epithelium forming twisted strips
    • Charcot-Leyden crystals: Sputum contains eosinophils and crystals derived from eosinophils
    • Creola bodies are seen in sputum
  • The bronchial wall shows
    • thickened basement membrane, submucosal edema
    • inflammatory infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes and plasma cells with prominence of eosinophils.
    • There is hypertrophy of smooth muscles and submucosal glands.

questions.text:
match the following
A) Breast cancer 1) S-100
B) Pancreatic cancer 2) CA 15.3
C) Stomach cancer 3) CA 19.9
D) Melanoma 4) CA 72.4
questions.solution:
PSA Prostate cancer
Ig Multiple myeloma
HCG Chorio carcinoma, Germ cell tumor
Calcitonin Medullary thyroid cancer
Catecholamines Neuroblastoma > Pheochromocytoma
CEA Colon cancer, Pancreatic cancer, IBD, Hepatitis, Bronchitis
AFP Hepato cellular cancer, Non seminomatus germ cell tumor, omphalocele, Hepatitis, pregnancy
CA 15.3 Breast cancer
CA 19.9 Pancreatic cancer, Colon cancer
CA 125 Ovarian cancer
NSF, Chromogranin Neuroblastoma, Small cell lung cancer
CA 72.4 Stomach cancer
CA 27.29 Breast cancer
S - 100 Melanoma, Schwannoma, LCH
LDH Lymphoma, Dysgerminoma / seminoma, Ewing’s sarcoma
Beta 2 Microglobulin Multiple myeloma
CD 99 (MiC 2) Ewings sarcoma

questions.text: A 62-year-old man complains of a severe mid-abdominal pain, just two days after admission to the hospital for a MI. Cardiac index: 1.6. There is no peritoneal irritation or distention. Serum lactate: 9 mmol/L (normal: < 3 mmol/L). The most appropriate next step in this patient’s management is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Abdominal pain, with no physical examination correlation: characteristic of intestinal ischemia.
  • The etiology of ischemia: embolic or thrombotic occlusion of the mesenteric vessels, or non occlusive ischemia because of a low cardiac index or mesenteric vasospasm.
  • Differentiation between these etiologies: done by mesenteric angiography.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is found to have high serum prostate–specific antigen (PSA) concentration with a normal prostate examination. A biopsy of the prostate confirms low-grade carcinoma. The patient wishes to avoid therapy involving any risk for impotence. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution: • Observation, or active surveillance, is an appropriate management option in a patient with early prostate cancer who wishes to avoid the risk of impotence involved with radiation, surgery, and hormonal therapy. Most early prostate cancers are slow-growing tumors and will remain confined to the prostate gland for a significant length of time. Active surveillance involves frequent visits to the doctor (every 3-6 months) with questions about new or worsening symptoms and digital rectal examinations for any change in the prostate gland. In addition, blood tests are done to watch for a rising PSA, and imaging studies can be conducted to detect the spread of the cancer. Chemotherapy is not indicated in the treatment of early-stage prostate cancer and is most often given to patients with metastatic disease who no longer respond to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A known case of HTN came for routine check up. She has complaints of painless oral ulcers, alopecia, photosensitive rash in face. Following are the drugs that causes drug induced lupus except
questions.solution:
Drug induced lupus

  • Drugs responsible are
    • S: Sulfonamides (Dapsone)
    • H: Hydralazine
    • I: Isoniazid
    • P: Procainamide
  • No kidney / brain involved
  • Drugs like infliximab, adalimumab can also cause drug induced lupus
  • Treatment: withdrawal of offending drugs
  • Steroids are used in treatment of SLE

questions.text: A patient with a diagnosed popliteal aneurysm is more likely to have which one of the following associations?
questions.solution:
• Popliteal aneurysms: 80% of all peripheral aneurysms
  • Popliteal aneurysms (50% are bilateral): most likely to have an associated aortic aneurysm (40% of cases) compared to other mentioned types of aneurysms.

questions.text:
Match principal actions of arachidonic acid metabolites in inflammation
A) vasodilation 1) Leukotrienes B4
B) vasoconstriction 2) PGE2
C) increased vascular permeability 3) Thromboxane A2
D) chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion 4) Leukotrienes E4
questions.solution:
vasodilation Prostaglandins PGD2, PGI2 , PGE1, PGE2
chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion HETE ; Leukotrienes B4
increased vascular permeability Leukotrienes C4, D4, E4
vasoconstriction Leukotrienes C4, D4, E4 ; Thromboxane A2

questions.text: In a 25-year-old woman with lower limb lymphoedema, which one of the following conditions is associated with lymphoedema?
questions.solution:
• Lymphoedema: can be primary and secondary
  • Primary lymphoedema: genetic cause, seen more commonly in females
  • Secondary lymphoedema:
    • post lymph node dissection
    • post radiotherapy
    • filariasis
    • post trauma
    • recurrent bacterial infections causing cellulitis

questions.text: Only one of the following statements regarding renal cell carcinoma is true. Choose the most appropriate answer.

choices.text: Women more commonly affected than men
RCC: accounts for 3% of all adult cancers

questions.solution:
• RCC: malignant cancer of proximal renal tubule cells
  • Accounts for around 3% of all adult cancers
  • Highly vascular malignancy
  • Slightly higher incidence in men than women.

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is a type of multisystem connective tissue disease. Which one of the following is not a pulmonary complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
• Rheumatoid lung: 20% cases, restrictive deficit secondary to fibrosis
  • Pleuritis: also common (5%), presents with chest pain and exudative pulmonary effusions.
  • Pulmonary nodules: histologically similar to cutaneous nodules; peripherally placed, asymptomatic, may cavitate.
  • Most common pulmonary RA manifestation: obstructive lung disease, 35%–50% of all RA pulmonary disease, patients with wheeze and exertional dyspnoea with an underlying bronchiolitis

  • Endoscopy + Biopsy
    • Abnormally appearing glands are seen

questions.text: A pregnant lady acquired chicken pox 3 days prior to her scheduled date of delivery. If she delivers the baby by normal vaginal route, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Both mother and baby are safe
Antiviral treatment should be given to mother before delivery
Antiviral treatment should be given to baby
Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome

questions.solution:
VARICELLAZOSTER INFECTIONS

  • 90% of adults have serological evidence of immunity
  • Primary infection → Varicella or Chickenpox
  • Transmitted by direct contact with an infected individual
  • Incubation period → 10 to 21 days
  • 1 to 2 days flu like prodrome followed by Pruritic Vesicular lesion that crust after 3 to 7 days
  • Period of communicability → 1 day before the onset of rash until lesions become crusted

MATERNAL MORTALITY

  • Predominantly d/t VZV (Pneumonia) in pregnancy
    • Risk Factors - Smoking, > 100 cutaneous lesions point towards poor prognosis
  • If there is reactivation of primary Varicella years later, it leads to Herpes Zoster or Shingles
    • U/L dermatomal Vesicular eruption
    • a/w severe pain
    • not more frequent or severe in pregnant women
    • Congenital Varicella syndrome rarely develops in cases of Maternal Herpes Zoster

FETAL & NEONATAL INFECTION CONGENITAL VARICELLA SYNDROME

  • The highest risk is b/w 13-20 weeks
  • Clinical Features
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral Cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypo-plasia
  • Cicatrial Skin Lesions
  • After 20 weeks of gestation, no clinical evidence of Congenital infection

AROUND DELIVERY

  • Active infection just before or during delivery (before Maternal antibody formed) is a serious threat.
    • Neonatal mortality rate is 30%
    • Disseminated Visceral & CNS disease is commonly fatal.
    • Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG) should be administered to neonates born to mothers who have clinical evidence of Varicella - 5 days before & up to 2 days after delivery.

DIAGNOSIS OF VARICELLA MATERNAL

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Confirmed by NAAT of vesicular fluid
  • Scraping the Vesicle base & go for Tzanck smear, Tissue culture or Direct Fluorescent antibody testing

FETAL → Congenital Varicella Dx with NAAT of Amniotic fluid

MANAGEMENT

MATERNAL EXPOSURE

  • Exposed pregnant women who are seronegative should be given VZIG
    • Best given with in 96 hrs of exposure
    • Can given up to 10 days

ESTABLISHED MATERNAL INFECTION

  • IV ACYCLOVIR therapy (at 10-15 mg/kg every 8 hrs) with hospitalization.

questions.text: A G3P3 patient had a past history of previous second trimester abortion. She presented with 22 weeks of gestation, abdominal pain. USG was taken which revealed funneling of internal os. What is the ideal management for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is Cervical incompetence
  • McDONALD’S OPERATION - The non-absorbable suture (Mersilene) material is placed as a purse string suture as high as possible (level of internal os) at the junction of the rugose vaginal epithelium and the smooth vaginal part of the cervix below the level of the bladder.
  • The suture starts at the anterior wall of the cervix. Taking successive deep bites (4–5 sites) it is carried around the lateral and posterior walls back to the anterior wall again where the two ends of the suture are tied.
  • The operation is simple having less blood loss, and has got a good success rate.
  • There is less formation of cervical scar and hence less chance of cervical dystocia during labor.

Postoperative care:

(1) The patient should be in bed for at least 2–3 days

(2) Weekly injections of 17 α hydroxy progesterone caproate 500 mg IM is given in women with history of prior preterm delivery

(3) Isoxsuprine (tocolytics) 10 mg tablet may be given thrice daily to avoid uterine irritability.

Advice on discharge

(a) Usual antenatal advice

(b) To avoid intercourse

(c) To avoid rough journey

(d) To report if there is vaginal bleeding or abdominal pain

(e) Periodic ultrasonographic monitoring of the fetus and the cervix.

Removal of stitch

  • The stitch should be removed at 37th week or earlier if labor pain starts or features of abortion appear.
  • If the stitch is not cut in time, uterine rupture or cervical tear may occur.
  • If the stitch is cut prior to the onset of labor, it is preferable to cut it in operation theater as there is increased chance of cord prolapse specially in the cases with floating head.

Contraindications

(i) Intrauterine infection

(ii) Ruptured membranes

(iii) History of vaginal bleeding

(iv) Severe uterine irritability

(v) Cervical dilatation > 4 cm.

Complications

(i) Slipping or cutting through the suture

(ii) Chorioamnionitis

(iii) Rupture of the membranes

(iv) Abortion/preterm labor

(v) Cervical lacerations during delivery

(VI) Cervical scarring and dystocia requiring cesarean delivery.

questions.text: All are true about anterior abdominal wall components, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Conjoint tendon is formed by 2/3 of external oblique and 1/3 internal oblique
Inguinal ligament formed by aponeurosis of external oblique
Lacunar ligament is extension of inguinal ligament
Interfoveolar ligament related to conjoint tendon

questions.solution:
• Conjoint tendonis formed byinternal oblique and transverse abdominisand not external oblique and internal oblique.

Other options:

  • Inguinal ligament is formed by aponeurosis of external oblique at its lower border.
  • Lacunar ligament is an extension of inguinal ligament and connects the inguinal ligament to thepectineal ligamentnear the point where they both insert on the pubic tubercle.
  • Interfoveolar ligament is related to conjoint tendon
  • Lateral to the conjoint tendon there is a ligamentous band originating from the lower margin of the transversalis fasciaand extending down in front of the inferior epigastric artery to the superior ramus of the pubis ; it is termed theinterfoveolar ligament of Hesselbach.

questions.text: A pregnant patient presented with fatigue and dizziness during her 2nd trimester. CBC revealed Hb – 10%, with increase reticulocyte count. Serum Iron was also low. You diagnose the case as nutritional anemia secondary to iron deficiency and decide to administer iron supplementation to the patient. Which of the following is a better absorbable oral form of Iron supplement?
questions.solution:
IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA IRON REQUIREMENT IN PREGNANCY

  • 1000 mg elemental Iron [4-6 mg/ day x 280 = 1120 mg]

500 mg → for Hb expansion

300 mg → for fetus, placenta

200 mg → wasted

MANAGEMENT

  • 100 mg / day elemental Iron Tab in ?"? pregnancy 200 mg / day elemental Iron in mild to moderate anemia
  • Oral Iron supplementation forms
    • Fe Sulphate
    • Fe Ascorbate Better Absorbable forms
    • Carbonyl Iron

Deworm the patient with MEBENDAZONE (100 mg Tab BD x 3 Days)

  • Injectable Preparations
    • Only indication → Intolerance or Malabsorption
    • Stop oral Iron at the time of giving injectables
    • Injectable Forms

1) Fe Dextran (IM/IV)

2) Fe Sorbitol [IM]

3) Fe Sucrose (iv) - No anaphylaxis (no test dose is given)

  • Rate of rise of Hb with Oral & Injectable preparation is same [1 gm% Hb rise over 2 ½ - 3 wks]

Requirement of Iron

  • 2.21 x wt in kg x (Targeted Hb – Pt Hb) + 1000 mg (for stores)
  • ≅ 200 mg / gm% Hb deficiency

  • Requirement of Blood for Rx of Anemia in pregnancy
    • Indications o Hb → <7 gm% or patient is severly anemic later in pregnancy
    • Whole blood ↑ Hb by 0.8 - 0.9 gm%
    • Packed cells ↑ Hb by 0.8 - 0.9 gm % [lesser volume load] [so better]
  • IDA Indices

1. Serum Ferritin

  • 1st parameter to change
  • ?"? - 40-160 ng/ml
  • IDA - < 20 ng/ml

2. Hb → ↓

3. MCV → ↓

4. MCH → ↓

5. Serum total Iron → < 50 µg/dl

6. Total Iron binding capacity → > 400 µg/dl

7. Red cell distribution width (RDW) → ↑

questions.text:
A G1P1 caucasian with a known history of alcohol intake beyond medical advise during prenatal period. After advise during an antenatal visit, she reduced the quantity of drinking only for the last three months of pregnancy. After delivery, which of the following features are needed to diagnose the case as Fetal alcohol syndrome?
(I) Small palpebral fissures
(II) Rail road track ears
(III) Thin vermilion border
(IV) Smooth philtrum
questions.solution:
FETAL ALCOHOL SYNDROME

  • All are required

1. Dysmorphic Facial features (all 3 required)

  • Small palpebral fissures
  • Thin vermilion border
  • Smooth Philtrum

2. Prenatal and / or postnatal growth impairment

3. CNS abnormalities (1 required)

  • Structural: Head size < 10th percentile, significant brain abnormality on imaging
  • Global cognitive or intellectual deficits

ALCOHOL RELATED BIRTH DEFECTS

1. Cardiac → ASD or VSD

2. Skeletal → Radio ulnar synostosis, joint contractures

3. Renal → Aplastic or hypoplastic kidneys

4. Eyes → Strabismus, Ptosis, Optic nerve hypoplasia

5. Ears → Conductive or Neuro-sensory hearing loss

6. Minor → Hypoplastic nails, Clinodactyly, Pectus carinatum or excavatum, Camptodactyly, Hockey stick Palmar crease, Rail Road Track Ears)

Twin Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

  • MC in MCDA > MCMA

MCMA has protective Arterio – Arterial

Anastomosis

Reverse the chances of TTTS in MCMA

Single fetal reduction

questions.text: USG of a 35 years old gravida patient revealed small grape like cystic structures without the evidence of a developing embryo. A diagnosis of a complete mole will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Genotype of the mole is a 46XXX and is completely paternal in origin
Genotype of the mole is triploid
Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein are elevated

questions.solution:
• In partial hydatidiform mole, the affection of the chorionic villi is focal. There is a fetus or at least an amniotic sac.
  • The karyotype is triploid either 69, XXY or 69, XYY with one maternal but usually two paternal haploid chromosomes.
  • Microscopic examination of the dilated chorionic villi shows predominant hyperplasia of the syncytiotrophoblast and presence of fetal blood vessels with fetal red blood cells.
  • The fetus, if present, dies in early first trimester. Rarely, the baby may be born which is growth retarded with multi-system abnormalities.
  • The clinical picture does not differ markedly from complete mole and too often confused with threatened or missed abortion.
  • The hCG titre is not markedly raised. With wider use of sonography, more and more cases are being revealed.
  • In partial mole, uterus is generally not large for dates and malignant potential is very low. Once the diagnosis is made and the fetus is not alive, termination of pregnancy is to be done.
  • Even if the fetus is alive, the patient should be warned about the risks involved to the fetus if pregnancy is continued.
  • Post-termination follow-up protocol should be the same as outlined in complete mole. As the chance of malignancy is much less, the follow up for 3–6 months is to be continued after hCG level returns t normal.
    Important Features of complete and partial moles
    Features Complete mole Partial mole
    Embryo/feus Absent Present
    Hydropic degeneration of villi Pronounced and diffused Variable and focal
    Trophoblast hyperplasia Diffuse Focal
    Uterine size More than the date (30-60%) Less than the date
    Theca lutein cysts Common (25-50%) Uncommon
    Karyotype 46 XX (85%) paternal in origin Triploid (90%) diploid (10%)
    ß hCG High (> 50,000) Slight elevation (<50,000)
    Classical clinical symptoms Common Rare
    Risk of Persistent (GTD) 20% <5%

questions.text: An 18 year old female complains of pain in the pelvis every month. Upon evaluation, it was noted that the pain was due to collection of blood and debris in the pouch of Douglas at the time of ovulation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MITTLESHMERZ/ MID CYCLE PAIN - d/t blood & debris (from follicle) collected into Pouch Of Douglas at the time of ovulation

DYSMENORRHEA (Pain of Menstruation)

During ovulation

↓

Prostaglandins are released (d/t rupture of oocyte)

↓

Causes contractions of uterine muscle to allow cervix to open for passage of shedded endometrium (by action of PG’s from CL)

↓

These contractions causes pain

TYPES

PRIMARY/SPASMODIC DYSMENORRHEA

  • Pain starts 30 min before onset of periods and stays 10 hrs post onset
  • Seen in normal women, women with fibroids

CONGESTIVE / SECONDARY DYSMENORRHEA

  • Pain starts 3-4 days prior and stays throughout menses
  • seen in PID & endometriosis

MEMBRANUOSDYSMENORRHEA

  • Fibrinolytic system in uterus is responsible for less/ non clumping of blood

questions.text: Anaerobic glycolysis occurs in conditions where oxygen is not present. It is wastage of glucose. Which of the following defines Warburg effect correctly?

choices.text: In the presence of oxygen, anaerobic glycolysis is inhibited in yeast cells
Oxygen consumption by yeast cell falls when supply is kept constant and glucose concentration is increased
Oxygen consumption by cancer cell falls when supply is kept constant and glucose concentration is increased
In the presence of oxygen, anaerobic glycolysis is inhibited in cancer cells

questions.solution:
Pasteur, Warburg and Crabtree effect

  • Aerobic glycolysis – 32 ATP produced by 1 glucose
  • Anaerobic glycolysis – 2 ATP produced by 1 glucose
  • 16 glucose to be used – 32 ATP
  • Anaerobic glycolysis is wastage of glucose

PASTEUR’S EFFECT

  • Occurs in normal cell
  • In the presence of O2, Anaerobic glycolysis is inhibited

WARBURG’S EFFECT

  • Occurs in cancer cells
  • Paradox from normal
  • Even in the presence of O2, glucose is converted to lactose
  • ‘KNOWN AS’ AEROBIC GLYCOLYSIS with NO oxidative phosphorylation
  • 2 ATPs are formed
  • Uses large amount of glucose to meet energy requirement.
  • Responsible for Cachexia
  • Lactate is the dead end of Glycolysis

CRABTREE EFFECT

  • When O2 supply is kept constant & glucose concentration is increased, then the O2 consumption by cell falls

↑ Glycolysis

↓

Glyceraldehyde 3 – phosphatase activity increases, has high affinity for pi

↓

Competes with ETC for pi (inorganic phosphate)

↓

ETC stops

↓

O2 consumption by cells falls

PASTEUR EFFECT CRABREE EFFECT
  • In aerobic conditions, glucose consumption Decreases

Or

  • In the presence of O2, anaerobic glucolysis is Inhibited
  • If glucose increases, then O2 consumption falls

or

  • When O2 supply is kept constant & glucose concentration is increased, then the O2consumption by cell falls

Warburg & Crabtree effect share common properties, but they are different

questions.text: An athlete is ready for a 100 metres dash. After the gunshot, he starts to run fast. The energy to his muscles is provided by which of the following fuel?
questions.solution:
Muscle energy systems Power (Rate of ATP production) Capacity (Total ATP produced) Fuel uses
Phosphagen system Very high Very low Creatine: Phosphate or Phospho- creatine
Anaerobic system/ Lactate system High Low Muscle glycogen
Aerobic system/ mito-chondrial respiratoin Low Very high Muscle glycogen, blood glucose, adipose tissue and intramuscular fat

Phosphagen system (First 3-10 seconds)

  • Quickest source of energy
  • Does not uses O2
  • Does not produce lactate
  • Most direct form of energy production
  • But phosphocreatine is of limited supply in muscles, so depleted quickly.

Anaerobic Glycolysis or Lactate system (1-3 minutes)

  • Produce ATPs using Glucose derived from Muscle Glycogen
  • Lactate is formed

Aerobic System or Mitochondrial Respiration (After 3 minutes)

  • uses carbohydrates, Fats, or Proteins to produce energy
  • Slowest but most efficient in providing energy
  • Uses TCA & ETC mainly
  • Provides more amount of energy (32 ATP from I glucose).

questions.text: A female after giving birth to three children decided to undergo tubectomy procedure. What is the most commonly performed technique for tubectomy?
questions.solution:
TECHNIQUES OF TUBECTOMY

  • Pomeroy Techniques
    • Most commonly done
    • Single ligature is used
    • Tube cut end are together
    • Can lead to fistula formation

POMEROY PROCEDURE

  • Parkland Technique
    • Double ligature is used
    • Tubes are ligated separately

PARKLAND

  • Irwing Procedure
    • One end of tube is anastamosed into uterine musculature
    • Other end of tube is anastamosed into mesosalpinx

IRWING

  • Sub Mucosal Disection of Tube (UCHIDA’S Procedure)
    • Serosa is lifted by needle & saline is injected
    • Then serosa is incised and tube is resected
    • Serosa is sutured again
    • Fibrosis & adhesions are very less, as cut ends are within the serosa.

UCHIDA’S

  • Madlener’s Method
    • Tubes are crushed, not resected.
    • High failure rates, not done these days.

MADLENER

  • Kroner’s Fimbriectomy
    • No reversal is possible
    • Not done these days

KRONER

questions.text: A previously healthy child developed bacterial meningitis. Supposing there are no specific contraindications, which one of the following is the DOC?

questions.text: A patient is taken to the ER after taking an overdose of her levothyroxine medication in a possible suicide attempt. Which of the following drugs would be administered first for immediate control of the hormonal effects of levothyroxine?

questions.text: A patient, at high risk of postmenopausal osteoporosis, has been started on alendronate. Which of the following is this bisphosphonate’s mechanism of action?

Reduction of number and activity of osteoclasts in the bone

questions.text: In a patient with steatorrhea as a result of pancreatic insufficiency secondary to cystic fibrosis, which one of the following medications is the most effective drug for steatorrhea management?

questions.text: The cardinal reason to avoid colchicine (2 doses - 12hours apart), even if it’s with a very short oral course, in a patient with acute gout, is the development of which one of the following medical occurrences?

  • Indomethacin is the preferred alternative in acute gout anti-inflammation or prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which one of the following diuretics should be avoided in a patient being treated for a severe infection with an aminoglycoside, as prevention of a more serious additive effect?
