questions.text: A new disinfectant manufactured by a company is subjected to be tested before getting into market. Which test tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when repeatedly used microbiologically in increasing load?
questions.solution:
TESTING OF DISINFECTANTS

PHENOL COEFFICIENT TEST/RADIAL NAEKER TEST

  • Determined by dilution of disinfectant
  • Used to sterilize suspension of salmonella typhi in given time divided by dilution of phenol which sterilizes suspension in same time
  • If Phenol coefficient > 1 → disinfectant is better than phenol
  • PHENOL COEFFICIENT TEST =

Highest dilution of test disnfections that kills S. typhi in given time / Highest dilution of phenol that kills S. typhi in given time

  • It does not assess activity in presence of organic waste

CHICK MARTIN TEST

  • Modification of RIDEAL WALKER CO EFFICIENT TEST
  • Checks Whether Disinfectant works in presence of organic waste [faeces, yeast] to simulate natural condition.

CAPACITY TEST [KELSEY SYKES TEST]

  • Capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when repeatedly used microbiologically in increasing load

IN USE TEST [KELSEY & MAURER TEST]

  • Disinfectant is microbiologically contaminated
  • Routinely performed in hospitals once in 3 months

questions.text: A 19 year old school student presented with fever, cough and also chest pain. A biopsy of lymph node revealed granulomatous inflammation and macrophages showed presence of oval structures measuring 2-4 microns. What is the likely cause of this patient?
questions.solution:
HISTOPLASMOSIS [DARLING’S DISEASE]

  • Systemic, granulomatous, intracellular infection
  • Affects Reticuloendothelial system
  • Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum [Dimorphic Fungi]
  • Source → Soil droppings of Pigeons & bat droppings and Bats. Fungus is found in these droppings
  • Mode of Transmission → Aerosol transmission in form of Multicellular filamentous mycelia
  • Incubation Period (IP) = 10-16 days
  • Lung involvement → Blood → Viscera

CLINICAL FEATURES

1. PULMONARY DISEASE

Acute Form Chronic Form

Influenza like disease

Resolves within 2-3 weeks

Shows lymphocyte rich infiltrate in lungs

Haemoptysis → resembles TB

Apical cavities → resembles TB

Calcification → resembles TB

2. CUTANEOUS & SUB CUTANEOUS DISEASE → Petechial lesions

3. DISSEMINATED DISEASE

  • Anemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Multiple lymphadenopathy LAB DIAGNOSIS

1. Sputum

2. Sternal Bone marrow

3. Lymph node

MICROSCOPY

  • Giemsa Stain
  • Gram’s Stain
  • Shows - Intracellular, Oval, Budding Yeast cells

CULTURE

  • SDA with Actidione
    • White Cottony mycelial growth with Tuberculate spores / Macroconidia [Mold form]
  • Potato dextrose agar

SEROLOGY

  • Immunodiffusion
  • Latex agglutination
  • Complement Fixation test
  • Histoplasmin Skin test -DTH [delayed type Hypersensitivity]

MOLD → TUBERCULATE MACROCONIDIA

YEAST → NARROW BASED BUDDING YEAST CELL

questions.text: A 6-year-old male chid was brought to hospital with the complaints of sore throat, high grade fever and drooling of saliva since 3-4 hours. Thumb sign is seen in the X ray taken for this child. Which of the following is not recommended to this patient?

  • Treatment

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child came with the complains of fever, barking cough, stridor. X ray was done and the image is given below. Which of the following sign is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Acute Laryngo- Tracheo Bronchitis (CROUP)

  • MC cause: Para influenza virus (Type 1,2)
  • Clinical features
    • Fever, barking cough, sore throat, Expiratory stridor
  • On examination
    • Sub coastal, inter coastal retraction
    • B/L conducted sound on auscultation
  • X- ray : Steeple sign
  • Treatment
    • Nebulization (with adrenaline, epinephrine)
    • Steroids
    • Antibiotics (to prevent bacterial infections)

Incorrect options

  • Thump sign: X-ray finding seen in acute Epiglottitis
  • Boyce sign, Bryce’s sign are seen in Laryngocele

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria along with pain in the pelvic region. Physical examination revealed enlarged prostate glands with tenderness. A diagnosis of Acute prostatitis was made. All of the following pathogens can be a cause in this patient, except?
questions.solution:
Prostatitis

  • Acute bacterial prostatitis
    • Characterized by typical irritative voiding symptoms urinary frequency, hesitancy, feeling of incomplete voiding, dribbling, fever, pyuria, and positive urine cultures
  • Chronic bacterial prostatitis
    • Characterized by the same voiding symptoms, but fever and pyuria are typically absent
  • Pathophysiology
    • Bacteria ascend the urethra, and then reflux into the prostatic ducts where infection occurs
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Acute Prostatitis
      • Patients appear ill with fever, chills, irritative voiding symptoms, and pelvic or perineal pain.
      • Physical examination reveals a very tender and enlarged prostate
    • Chronic Prostatitis
      • Symptoms are more subtle .
      • Patients may present with Recurrent UTI
      • Prolonged treatment of prostatitis cures the disease
  • Pathogens
    • Gram negative rods, Enterobactericeae (eg. Escherichiacoli, Kiebsiella and Proteus species), Pseudomonas
    • N. gonorrhoeae and C trachomatic cause prostatitis, in a/w urethiritis and epididymitis in sexually active men
  • Diagnosis
    • Edematous and tender prostate
    • Urine culture → Done to determine causative organisms
    • Prostatic fluid culture → Not done in Acute Prostatitis because prostatic massage should not be done during the acute phase
    • Prostatic massage may be useful in Chronic Prostatitis
  • Treatment
    • Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole or Ciprofloxacin can be used as empiric therapy until culture results return
  • These agents exhibit good penetration into the prostate. Therapy is prolonged (4 to 6 weeks)

questions.text: A 52 year male came with the complaints of otalgia, pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss. On examination he was diagnosed with Glomus tumor. Which of the following sign is not seen in case of Glomus tumor?
questions.solution:
Signs seen in case of Glomus tumor

  • Rising sun sign: Reddish blue rising from hypo tympanum
  • Aquino sign
  • Brown sign: On seigelization, tumor blanches and becomes white
  • Phelps sign: Inability to distinguish between internal carotid artery and jugular bulb due to erosion of caroticojugular crest; Seen in CT
  • Schwartz sign: Seen in otosclerosis; Flaming pink blush of TM; Seen during active stage of disease

questions.text: A 55 year old male came with the complains of nasal mass, nasal obstruction and bleeding. Biopsy was taken and the histopathology finding is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ringertz tumor / Inverted papilloma

  • MC benign tumor of nasal cavity
  • Male : female - 3.5 : 1
  • Arises from Schneiderian membrane ( transitional cell epithelium)
  • Presentation
    • Polypoidal mass arising from lateral wall of nasal cavity
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Bleeding
  • Investigation
    • IOC: Biopsy and HPE shows inverted infolding papilloma (confirmatory)
  • CECT
    • To know the spread
    • Hyperdense homogeneous mass
  • Treatment
    • Endoscopic excision (TOC)
    • Chances of recurrence and conversion into squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: According to 90 IPC following are considered as invalid consent except

choices.text: Consent from a person who is Intoxicated
Consent from a person who is under the Influence of threat
Consent given by 14 yrs old rape victim for physical examination

questions.solution:
• Any consent given due to following are considered as invalid consent (90 IPC)
    • Insanity
    • Intoxication
    • Influence of threat, drug, etc
    • Child <12 years
  • Consent is not needed in
    • Emergency ( life threatening situations)
    • Waiver
    • Doctrine of extended consent
  • Minimum age for giving consent for physical examination is 12 years

12 hours Monocytes in exudate

questions.text: A 17-year-old female was brought to emergency room. Patient’s parents said that she was bit by a dark black colored snake which has hexagonal scales on dorsum of the body. What is most likely to be seen in this patient ?
questions.solution:
King cobra, Common cobra, Krait Neurotoxic
Russells viper, Saw scaled viper, Hump nosed viper Hemotoxic / Vasculotoxic
Sea snake Myotoxic

Krait

  • Dark black
  • On dorsum of the body it has hexagonal scale
  • 4th infralabial scale is the largest

King cobra

  • Largest venomous snake
  • It can grow upto 4 meters
  • Commonly seen in western ghats

Common cobra

  • It can grow upto 1 meter
  • It has spectate mark (binocellate)
  • 3rd supralabial scale is the largest

Russells viper

  • Markings on the body ( spectate shape)

Saw scale viper

  • There is presence of arrow mark on its head

Neurotoxic features

  • Ptosis, Diplopia, Flaccid descending paralysis, Respiratory failure

Vasculotoxic features

  • DIC, Cardiotoxic features (shock, hypotension, arrhythmia)

Myotoxic features

  • Pain, muscle tenderness, swelling, myonecrosis/ lysis

questions.text: A diabetic patient was diagnosed cellulitis and the causative agent is shown on gram stain. On antibiotic sensitivity testing, it was found to be methicillin resistant. All of the following antibiotics will be appropriate for this patient, except?
questions.solution:
S. aureus BLOOD AGAR α, β, γ HEMOLYSIS

  • Gram positive cocci
  • Catalase +ve
  • Coagulase +ve
  • Gram staining → Grape like clusters (purple to violet)
  • CULTURE MEDIA

1) NA [Nutrient Agar] → Golden yellow pigmentation

↓

Enhances on milk agar

Golden Yellow Colonies on NA

2. BA [Blood Agar]

  • causes β hemolysis → Complete zone of hemolysis
  • pin head size colonies
  • VIRULENCE FACTORS

1) Thickness of peptidoglycan layer

2) Teichoic acid

3) Clumping factor

4) Protein A

  • Is present in COWAN-1 strain of Staph. aureus
  • plays a role in co-agglutination
  • has a property of binding with the Fc portion of Ig G

HEMOLYTIC FACTORS

5) Hemolysins (α, β, γ, δ)

  • α Hemolysins
    • shows paradoxical action
    • Inactivities at 70° C
      • Reactivities at 100° C
  • β Hemolysins / sphingomyelins
    • shows HOT & COLD PHENOMENON
      • β Hemolysis starts at 37° C
      • in S. aureus best seen at 4° C
  • γ Hemolysin + PV Toxin [Panton Valentine Toxin] 00:27:52
    • Gives SYNERGOHYMENOTROPIC action [↑virulence of Staph. aureus]

6) Leucocidin [Panton Valentine Toxin]

  • Kills leucocytes

7) Enzymes

  • DNAase
  • Thermonuclease
  • Coagulase [plays the most important role in pathogenicity & virulence]
    • Tube coagulase → free form of coagulase → Better & more confirmatory
    • Slide coagulase → Bound form of coagulase
  • Hyaluronidase
  • Lipase
  • Phosphatase
  • Other Diseases a/w S. aureus

i) Cellulitis

ii) Bullous Impetigo

iii) Carbuncles

iv) Furuncles

v) Acute osteomyelitis

vi) Acute mastitis

vii) Post op. parotitis

viii) Epidural / subdural abscess

ix) MCC of early PVE: S. aureus

x) MCC of native valve endocarditis

xi) Iv drug abuser → Rt sided valve endocarditis

xii) Pnemonia → Pneumatocele

xiii) Botryomycosis → Mycetoma like lesion

xiv) Tropical pyomyositis

MRSA [Methicillin Resistant Staph. Aureus]

  • DOC → vancomycin (a/w RED MAN SYNDROME)
  • Mechanism of resistance

(1) PBP (Transpeptidase) → PBP 2a [main mechanism]

(PBP-Penicillin Binding Protein)

d/t MEC A gene aquisition;

MEC A GENE TYPES [6 TYPES]

I Causes NosocomialMRSA

II Causes Nosocomial MRSA

↓

III > 48 hrs of admission in hospital

IV Cause community Acquired MRSA

V Cause community Acquired MRSA

VI Cause community Acquired MRSA

(2) Production of β Lactamases (Pencillinases) LAB DIAGNOSIS

  • Screening Tests

(1) CEFOXITIN

↓

Resistant

↓

MRSA (100%)

OXACILLIN

↓

Resistant

↓

MRSA (90%)
  • Method: KBDDT
  • Done on MHA [Muller-Hinton Agar]/ NA
  • Add 4% NaCl
  • Keep temperature of incubation → <37° C [30° -35°]

(2) ELISA for MEC A gene

(3) PCR for MEC A gene [best screening test for MRSA]

(4) Latex Agglutination Test for PBP2a

  • Contact isolation done for MRSA
  • Mupirocin ointment or Bacitracin ointment indicated for nasal carriers
  • Best method to prevent nosocomical spread → Hand washing

questions.text: A 27-year-old female was brought to government hospital for post-mortem examination. Police officer said to the physician that the female died of drowning. Given are the signs of drowning except?
questions.solution:
• Sueshnihov’s sign: Presence of H2O in sinuses (maxillary/ sphenoid)
  • Sehrt’s sign: Micro ruptures of wall of the stomach due to stretching
  • Wydler’s sign: When the gastric fluid from the stomach is kept in the beaker for 1 hour we can see 3 layers
  • Ueno’s sign: Presence of H2O in middle ear
  • Sabinsky’s sign: Because of drowning spleen looks small and anemic

Incorrect option

  • Amussat sign: Transverse intimal tears seen in carotid artery injury; Post-mortem finding seen in case of hanging.

questions.text: A mentally child is found by his father with an unknown substance in his mouth. He initially had a headache, then there was agitation and confusion. The child had a seizure in the ER, on presentation to the hospital and there was dysrhythmia on the cardiac monitor. ABG analysis shows severe metabolic acidosis. Which of the following agents is most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Cyanide:, rodenticide found in rural areas
  • Cyanide poisoning: rapid treatment with a cyanide antidote kit along with high levels of O2

questions.text: In a child who is immunized completely, a throat swab was collected. It revealed the presence of gram positive rods. The causative agent can have which one of the following properties on further laboratory processing?

choices.text: It can grow on Potassium tellurite medium
It would show a positive Elek’s gel precipitation test
It can be pathogenic to experimental guinea pigs
It can produce cytotoxicity in tissue cultures

questions.solution:
CORYNEBACTERIUM DIPHTHERIA (Kleb Loffler’s Bacillus) \

GRANULES

Metachromatic granules/ Polymetaphosphate granules/ Volutin Granules/ Babes ernest granules

  • These are Energy deposits
  • Stained by

P → Ponders Stain

A → Alberts Stain

N → Neisser Stain

  • Cuneiform arrangement/Chinese letter pattern

Chinese Letter Pattern

DIPHTHERIA

  • Pseudo membrane (characterstic) (Greyish white membrane)
  • MC site: Faucial
  • Bleeds on touch
  • Most dangerous → laryngeal
  • Complication : Bull Neck → Neck edema
  • Chronic complication: polyneuropathies of myocarditis

Lab Diagnosis

Throat swab

− Gram staining

Culture on:

- LSS (Loeffler’s Serum Slope)

↓

For early diagnosis (6-8 hrs)

- PTA → Definitive diagnosis best selective media

OTHER CULTURE MEDIA’s

H → Hoyle’s media

M → Macleod’s media

T → Tinsdale media

GS/AS → Cuneiform agents

TOXIN DEMONSTRATION

1) Elek Gel Precipitation Test

2) PCR For tox gene

3) ELISA For toxin Production

SCHICK TEST

Determines susceptibility of an individual to diphtheriae

If positive → needs immunization

If negative → already immunized

Neutralization test
  • Diphtheria is TOXEMIA not Bacteremia
  • Every corynebacterium diphtheriae is not pathogenic, but made pathogenic by®phage tox gene → LYSOGENIC CONVERSION

Lysogenic Phase Part of Transduction

Lytic Phase [Bacteriophage mediated]

CUTANEOUS DIPHTHERIA

  • Punched out ulcerative lesion
  • Not toxin mediated

Rx:

  • ADS
    • Anti Diphtheric Serum
    • In severe cases: 80,000-1,00,000 units
  • Antibiotic:
    • Penicillin or Erythromycin
    • Better to give in initial stage of disease i.e., before toxin production
  • For carriers: Erythromycin
  • Protective Titers against Diphtheria
    • Antitoxin titer ≥ 0.01 unit/mL (Following vaccination)

questions.text: Which one of the following is a contraindication tion to breast-feeding?

questions.text: A farmer presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever and flu like symptoms. On examination, inguinal lymphadenopathy was seen which was painful and also an ulcer in leg. Which of the following stains should be used to detect the suspected bipolar stained causative agent?
questions.solution:
YERSINIAPESTIS

  • Leads to Plague (Zoonotic infection)

Culture Media

  • Ghee broth
  • Stalactite type of growth

Virulence Factors

i) F1 Ag → Plasmid borne → Heat labrile capsular Ag (inhibit macrophage phagocytosis)

ii) Phospholipase

iii) PH 6 Ag → Fibrilar protein → Binding to lipoprotein

iv) LPS → Endotoxic activity

v) Siderophore

  • TYPES

1) B → Bubonic → IP → 2-7 Days

2) S → Septicaemic → IP → 2-7 Days

3) P → Pneumonic → IP → 1-3 Days [most Dangerous]

BUBONIC PLAGUE

  • MC type
  • MOT: Bite (Rat Flea)

↓

Lymphatics

↓

Multiplies

  • IP: 2-7 days
  • Buboes: Regional LN

Tense & Tender

  • Bubonic Plague can’t spread from Person to Person

PNEUMONIC PLAGUE

  • IP: 1-3 days
  • MOT: Inhalation of bacilli in droplets expelled from another person or an animal
  • Rare: < 1%
  • Agent of Bioterrorism

Clinical Features

Fever, headache & pneumonia like features

SEPTICAEMIC PLAGUE

  • LPS: Endotoxic shock
  • IP: 2-7 days
  • Massive involvement of blood vessels → Gangrene → Black death

Lab Diagnosis

Bubonic → Buboes smear (Pus or Fluid)

Pneumonic → sputum & blood

Septicaemic → Blood & splenic aspirate

Transport Media: Carry Blair

Direct Microscopy

  • Presence of pus cells & GNCB
  • Wayson stain or Methylene blue stain
    • Bipolar stained appearance

or

Safety pin appearance

Bipolar Staining Culture:

  • Ghee broth → stalactite growth
  • Pleomorphism is also shown
  • F1 Ag detection
  • PCR for Y. Pestis

DOC: Streptomycin

Prophylaxis: Doxycycline

  • “Cheopis Index” → for plague

Vaccine

  • Haffkine vaccine
    • Sokhey’s modification (killed vaccine)
    • Live attenuated is also there but not routinely given

questions.text: The recent death of a 45 year old uncle, from MI, of a 2-month-old baby boy has caused the baby’s parents some concern about his risk of CAD. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Screening of parents for total cholesterol
Yearly ECGs are recommended for this patient
Reduce the infant’s dietary fat by giving him skim milk.

questions.solution:
• Children with a first or second degree relative with early onset CAD: evaluated early in life, after 2 years of age.
  • No change in infant dietary practice is recommended for children under 2 years of age

questions.text: A 32 year-old woman presents to the OPD with a lesion on the extensor surface of the right elbow, 2.4 cm in diameter, raised with a flat top and distinct edge. There is an excess accumulation of stratum cornea over the lesion and multiple smaller lesions also located on extensor surfaces. Which term best describes the primary lesion?
questions.solution:
• Raised lesions: papules, nodules, tumors, or plaques.
  • A plaque: raised lesion with a flat top, larger than 1 cm in diameter
  • Papules: smaller than 0.5 cm
  • Nodules: 0.5–5.0 cm
  • Tumors: more than 5 cm.
  • Macules (less than 2cm) and patches (more than 2cm) are not raised.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman with a 6 year history of psoriasis (involving her elbows) has been on topical glucocorticoids and a vitamin D analogue. In the past 9 months, her psoriasis has worsened. She now has developed new lesions on her knees, gluteal regions, and scalp, as well as swelling of her digits with pain and stiffness. There is no systemic infection. All of the following therapies will worsen widespread psoriatic disease EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate: effective in patients with psoriatic arthritis
  • Cyclosporine: effective in psoriasis
  • Alefacept is an intramuscular biologic: indicated in psoriasis.
  • However, these are all associated with an increased risk of serious systemic infection, neurologic events, and hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about sunburn is true?

choices.text: UV B radiation causes maximum development of sunburn at midday.
Red haired and fair skinned: have high activity of melanocortin-1 receptor
UVB: more effective at causing sunburn erythema than UVA
Lag time from sun exposure to development of visible redness: 1–2 hours.

questions.solution:
• Sunburn: acute inflammatory reaction of skin to sunlight, mostly due to the UVB radiation.
  • Sunburn erythema: due to vasodilation of dermal blood vessels
  • Lag time of 4–12 hours after sun exposure to development of visible redness.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman is started on glyburide 10mg sustained release tablets OD for type 2 diabetes mellitus. She develops an erythematous rash, after spending an afternoon in the garden. Which of the following features cause a suspicion of photoallergy over phototoxicity?

choices.text: Persistent hypersensitivity to light after cessation of drug

questions.solution:
• Sulfonylurea medications: cause both photoallergy and phototoxicity reactions
  • Phototoxicity: nonimmunologic reaction that occurs without a latency period after drug ingestion. Like a sunburn, a phototoxic reaction blisters and desquamates.
  • Photoallergic reaction: occurs when UV rays transform drug into an unstable hapten capable of stimulating an immune response (delayed hypersensitivity that is intensely pruritic), the sun-exposed areas appear lichenified and leathery. This phenomenon continues even after the cessation of sulfonylureas.

questions.text: A 11 month old infant with poor weight gain, persistent cough, has a history of multiple bouts of pneumonitis. The parents gave a history of the child have large, foul-smelling stools for months. Which of the following diagnostic tests are mandated to provide an accurate diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cystic fibrosis: a multisystem disease caused by an abnormally functioning cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein
  • Abnormal secretions: produced due to decreased permeability of ionized chloride in the secretory epithelium of organs (especially lungs).
  • There is almost no overlap in sweat chloride values in patients with CF and normal control participants. Hence it is used for a more accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: An alert, awake infant with a 3 day history of diarrhea presents to the ER with tachycardia, sunken eyes, loss of elasticity of skin and a depressed fontanelle. Which of the following is the right percentage of dehydration in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Moribund state: loss of more than 10% of body weight due to dehydration.
  • Other findings: shows loss of body weight of 5% to 9%, with no hypernatremia.
  • Additional findings in this case: restlessness, reduced or absent tears, reduced radial pulses and orthostatic hypotension.

questions.text: An 87 year old woman with multiple medical comorbidities, sustains a fracture of her humerus. The arm is placed in a sling and a no-operation decision is made. After 3 months, the patient still hasn’t recovered normal limb function. There is also an absence of callus over the fracture site. What is the possible complication in this case?
questions.solution:
• Malunion: fracture heals in an abnormal position
  • Delayed union: fracture heals normally but longer period of time
  • Non-union: the fracture surfaces fail to unite; there are two types
    • hypertrophic: there is an abundance of callus but no union
    • atrophic: no callus formation

questions.text: A patient presents to his GP surgery complaining of a swelling on his wrist. On examination of a patient who presented with a focal swelling on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, it is smooth and non-tender, the overlying skin is normal and has free movement over the mass. However, it appears to be fixed to the tendon. Likely diagnosis is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• The lump is not fixed to the skin, so sebaceous cyst is ruled out
  • Fixation to the tendon rules out lipoma, since there is no fatty tissue in tendons.
  • Fibroma and giant cell tumours: extremely rare
  • Ganglion: a cystic degeneration of fibrous tissue, occur around joints and tendon sheaths

questions.text: The parents of a 3year old male child state that the child has cheese-like, white material occurring from his foreskin, and he cannot fully retract the foreskin behind the glans penis. What would be the correct website in this case?

choices.text: Paraphimosis, child requires a circumcision and topical antibiotics

questions.solution:
• During the first 3 years of life in male children, adhesions between the glans and the prepuce get lysed → distal portion of the foreskin loosens → glans is exposed.
  • There is collection of debris (cellular) under the foreskin; and while it may seem abnormal, it requires no treatment.

questions.text: A patient, who is undergoing a detailed neurological exam for sciatica, following signs are elicited: sensory loss over outer calf and dorsum of foot, weakness in dorsiflexion of toes, normal knee reflexes, normal ankle reflexes, painful straight leg raise, normal femoral nerve stretch. At which one of the following levels is the disc protrusion?
questions.solution:
• Sensory loss: L5 nerve root compression, which is also proven by weakness in dorsiflexion of the foot (tibialis anterior and peroneus tertius) with sparing of the knee (L3, L4) and ankle (S1, S2) reflexes.
  • Lumbar disc protrusion does not affect the nerve exiting above the disc. Therefore, lateral protrusion of the L4/5 disc spares the L4 spinal nerve, but it compresses the L5 spinal nerve.

questions.text: Which one, out of the following bone pathologies, is not correctly matched to the most common site at which it occurs?

choices.text: Enchondroma – Bones of hands and feet
Osteosarcoma – Femur, just above the knee

questions.solution:
• Enchondromas and ecchondromas: benign cartilage growths in centre or surface of a bone, respectively.
  • Occur in the hands and feet
  • Rarely affect long bones
  • Osteomas: benign bone tumours of the cranial vault.
  • Osteosarcomas: most common sites are distal femur —> proximal tibia —> proximal humerus, in the order of prevalence
  • Osteomyelitis: bacterial seeding of the metaphysis and subsequent infection in the ends of long bones. Mid-shaft is rarely affected.

questions.text: In a 7 year old child with repeated episodes of otitis media, there is an uneventful surgical placement of pressure-equalization tubes. She soon develops a fever of 104°F, muscle rigidity and metabolic as well as respiratory acidosis. Which of the following is the explanation for her condition?
questions.solution:
• Malignant hyperthermia:
    • Tachycardia
    • arrhythmia
    • tachypnea
    • cyanosis
    • myoglobinuria
    • elevated serum creatine kinase levels
    • evidence of acute renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding a situation in which a bat is found in the bedroom of a 5 year old sleeping boy? The family and the patient himself denies any bites or contact with the bat.

choices.text: Therapy only if patient has signs of rabies infection.

questions.solution:
• Dogs: most frequent vector of rabies infection
  • Other potential vectors: skunks, bats, foxes, and coyotes.
  • The CDC recommends that postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) even without an obvious bat bite.
  • PEP consists of:
    • wound cleansing (if there is a wound)
    • rabies immune globulin (RIG)
    • five injection rabies vaccine series

questions.text: About the spleen, all of the following statements are true, except:

choices.text: it lies posterior to the axillary line, adjacent to 9th and 11th ribs.
On USG, spleen is equal to or less than 14 cm on its longest axis

questions.solution:
• Spleen: mesenchymal origin and is formed by numerous splenunculi which fuse.
  • Ten percent of unfused or accessory splenunculi are demonstrated on USG or CT, usually in the region of the hilum or lienorenal ligament.

questions.text: All of the below mentioned statements are true regarding skeletal imaging, except? (a) Phased array surface detection coils improve signal:noise ratio in MRI of bone, joint and soft tissues

choices.text: Phased array surface detection coils improve signal:noise ratio in MRI of bone, joint and soft tissues
Cortical bone and calcification abnormalities are usually not detected by MRI.
Bone scans using 99mTc MDP are extremely specific.
Fat fluid level within the suprapatellar bursa: indicates a fracture within the knee joint

questions.solution:
• A three-phase study is used:
    • immediate vascular images (0.3 minutes)
    • blood-pool phase (3–5 minutes)
    • delayed static images (4–6 hours).
  • Bone scan is very sensitive to the presence of any pathology, but is non-specific.

questions.text: A 60 year old smoker presents with dyspnea on exertion and has progressively worsened over 10 months. On physical examination, resting O2 saturation: 95%. After walking for 100 meters, his saturation is 83%. He requires oxygenation at 3 L/min to maintain his O2 sats at greater than 90%. Lung examination: diffuse end-inspiratory crackles in both lungs. TLC: 72% predicted, RV: 68% predicted, and diffusing capacity: 60%. CT scan is shown below. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is suspected. What would be the expected surgical pathology finding?
questions.solution:
• Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis:
    • progressive dyspnea on exertion and dry cough in an older individual
    • Rare in individuals younger than 50 years
    • inspiratory crackles and clubbing
    • Interstitial fibrosis that is worse in bases and which begins in the subpleural areas
    • associated with traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing.

questions.text: In a patient with assumed granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which of the following lung radiologic findings is least likely to be found?
questions.solution:
• The typical CXR in Wegener’s: single or multiple nodular infiltrates that often cavitate
  • There is frequent involvement of airways, hence tracheal or bronchial stenosis may occur
  • Ground glass infiltrates: due to capillaritis and subsequent pulmonary hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about anomerism?

choices.text: Two carbons combine with each other when solution form converts to powder form
Functional carbon always combines with the second last carbon
Different H and OH orientation asymmetric functional carbon give rise to anomerism
C1 is the functional carbon for aldoses and C2 for ketoses

questions.solution:
ANOMERISM

Linear Structures Cyclic Structures

[Powder form] [Solution form]

  • The combining carbons are Functional carbons; Always combine with 2nd last carbon
  • When linear structure converts to cyclic structure, two carbons combine with each other.
  • For Aldoses, C1 is functional carbon, for ketoses C2 is the functional carbon.
  • The functional carbon changes from symmetric to asymmetric.
  • Different H and OH orientation around this asymmetric functional carbon gives rise to anomerism.

  • Only for cyclic form
